event_text:
The start of the year that NYPD's Stop-and-Frisk
program peaks at 685,724 recorded stops.

'Amid criticism about the way New York City police
officers enforce marijuana laws, Commissioner
Raymond W. Kelly issued a memo to commanders
this week reiterating that officers are not to arrest
people who have small amounts of marijuana in their
possession unless it is in public view.'

Floyd v. City of New York and a subsequent NYPD
mandate that required officers to thoroughly justify the reason
for making a stop. Stop-and-Frisk on the decline.
Bill De Blasio begins term as NYC's 109th Mayor.

'Starting Nov. 19, people found with 25 grams or
less of marijuana may get a court summons and a
fine of up to $100 -- provided they aren't smoking
or burning the drug. Previously, having marijuana
in the public view meant a visit to a station house,
fingerprinting and misdemeanor charges.'

'NYC Mayor Bloomberg says no more overnight
jail stays for minor pot arrests.'

'Manhattan District Attorney Cy Vance announced
that his office is changing its plea guidelines for
marijuana arrests to lighten penalties for first-
and second-time offenders effective Tuesday...'

'...[N]ot quite legalization but the NYPD officially will no
longer arrest most people caught smoking marijuana
in public although police will still handcuff people in
some circumstances.

Possession of up to two ounces or less of marijuana in New York
State will be treated as a violation instead of a crime,
with fines dropping to as low as $50.
